title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (October 17, 2019).

The UAW struck a tentative labor deal with GM, a critical step in ending a strike that has brought over 30 of the car maker's U.S. factories to a standstill.

Netflix missed its subscriber-growth target, but shares rose 10% after hours as growth in the U.S. subscriber base calmed investor fears.

J&J has offered to pay about $4 billion to settle all lawsuits in the U.S. accusing the company of contributing to the opioid crisis.

BofA's profit was dented by a one-time charge, but the lender posted gains in its consumer, wealth and commercial businesses.

IBM posted a fifth sequential quarter of falling sales amid Rometty's efforts to revive growth through the Red Hat acquisition.

Barneys reached a deal to sell its assets to Authentic Brands and B. Riley Financial that calls for the chain to close its remaining stores.

Shoppers pulled back on spending in September, signaling a key support for the U.S. economy this year could be softening.

U.S. stocks lost ground as economic data fueled concerns about growth. The S&P 500 and Dow fell 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively.

China's Huawei reported accelerated revenue growth for the third quarter despite its U.S. export blacklisting.

Britain's antitrust watchdog has launched a formal probe into Amazon's investment in Deliveroo.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 17, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
